fields.description:
To keep it simple, many of the internal cross-refs in the Console Guide are plain text, with no actual link. For example:  "For more information on Auto Scaling, -please- see _Using Auto Scaling_ in the _Eucalyptus User Guide_."

This is not ideal when the user is reading the Console Guide HTML docs; they are not links. It's also easy for doc content to go out of date because, if the referenced topic goes away or moves, the cross-reference does not obviously break; it's easy to forget them.

However, plain text works in the PDF (rather than making it look like a link (blue and underlined), then not actually go anywhere).

Plain text also works for the product GUI help. In this case, the Euca HTML docs' URL is problematic. We do not currently use the "latest" convention (e.g., http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/using-instance-addressing.html) for our most current release; instead the version # is embedded in the URL (e.g., http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.3.0/#user-guide/autoscaling_intro.html).

We can:
1. change all cross-refs to plan text with consistent style (e.g., italics, topic name, followed by guide name).
2. consider implementing the "latest" convention with our new web site.
3. do something else.
fields.summary: Design the best style for cross-refs to the docs from within online help

comments.body:
FWIW, on the new web server I'm setting things up with a directory for each release, along with links to both the latest release in each series and the latest release overall, like this:

* /eucalyptus/4.2.0
* /eucalyptus/4.2.1
* /eucalyptus/4.2.2
* /eucalyptus/4.2 -> 4.2.2
* /eucalyptus/4.3.0
* /eucalyptus/4.3.1
* /eucalyptus/4.3 -> 4.3.1
* /eucalyptus/latest -> 4.3

This will allow people to access each release's documentation when that is truly necessary, while at the same time allowing things like eucaconsole to generically link to the latest documentation for a given series.

Once the new doc site is ready, will fix this https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/commit/5c4f37367b1d6b59d02d98bc697c1daf82323311
(we will try "latest" instead)

This is great. I've hoped we could institute this for a while.
One question about the config [~gholms] mentions. Is the deployment for the docs server all scripted, chef, cloud formation, etc, but something so that it's repeatable and under version control?

The web server is managed with puppet.  The building and publication process is a Jenkins job whose history is tracked by the [Job Config History|https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/JobConfigHistory+Plugin] plugin.  Already-published documentation will be backed up with rsnapshot.  Symlink management is currently manual, but infrequent and backed up along with the content.

[~dkavanagh], [~kgill]

Something to consider about using the 'latest' variant of the docs.eucalyptus.com url format for console online help:

#  Would older versions of console online help cause confusion for the user or become incorrect if linking to a xref of 'latest' documentation...
# If the answer is yes to (1), we could implement a recurring task where all of the xref doc links in the console online help are updated to match the console version for the new release. If we use the two-digit release number (e.g. 4.4), this task would only need to be done at a feature release. (the https://docs.eucalyptus.com/eucalyptus/4.4/ will redirect to the current dot release)

[~khadges]: Linking the "latest" console docs to older online help would be confusing for users, especially for major and minor release updates (e.g. 5.0 docs link to 4.4 online help, or 4.4 links to 4.3 help).  Patch releases should be fine, however (e.g. 4.4.1 docs link to 4.4.0 online help).
[~kgill] Excellent -- my thoughts as well. I'll implement a process so the xref doc urls in Online Help are always in lock-step with the console major version series.
How specific are the versions you intend to use in these xrefs?  If it is more specific than the series (e.g. 4.4) then we risk bad links when eucaconsole and eucalyptus versions do not match.

[~kmeredith] This is an overview of one way the console online help urls can be managed without compromising the documentation source or user experience. Thoughts?

# Set up [DITA profiling|https://www.oxygenxml.com/doc/versions/18.1/ug-editor/topics/profiling-conditional-text.html] in the documentation source so that we can include both _source_ xrefs (relative urls) and console-help xrefs (full url for a version series (e.g. 4.4)) in the same topic. This ensures that the user experience is consistent for both the online documentation (relative links) and the console online help (full urls that open in a new tab/window)- and is all managed in the documentation source.
# Whenever there is a feature release (e.g. 5.0), update the console-help urls in the documentation source, transform to xhtml and update of the online help with the new series urls. (this process will be documented on the [Producing Console Online Help|https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/DOC/Producing+Console+Online+Help+Content] wiki page). This should minimize the number of updates for existing topics.

If you have ideas for a more efficient method, let me know.

Per conversation with [~kgill] and [~dkavanagh] - suggest we target 5.0.0 to introduce new hyperlinks and only focus on updating the two topics that are using docs.hpcloud.com. 

To keep consistent UX with the other help topics, recommend to remove the hyperlinks on these two topics and then introduce all doc xref hyperlinks correctly in 5.0.0.

@tbex - [~alice] will have two help topics to review - does this work for the QA timeline?


https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/blob/master/eucaconsole/static/html/help/console_bucket_detail.html
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/blob/master/eucaconsole/static/html/help/console_instance_detail.html
[~khadges]: https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/2201 looks good, but if those changes are needed for 4.4.1 we should open the pull request against the maint-4.4 branch instead of master.
